Pros: Flex Time Off, everyone works hard to get the job done
Cons: A lot of overnight work has impacted my work-life balance."

Pros: The opportunity to work from home was the best thing about this role.
Cons: Don't report training issues or you will be fired. I agree with a previous comment that this is not a good place for minorities (in my opinion); specifically Black Americans. These people required me to repeat a training class that I'd already completed and passed 8 months prior because they didn't want to provide adequate mentor assistance (something they claimed would be available when requested). Their reason for me repeating? Because I had complained about the previous training session, although I wasn't the only person who had complained. However, I was the only employee required to repeat the session. I was even told (by a manager) that my comments might "offend the mentors who had worked hard on the training material". Then, to add insult to injury, I was terminated the day after I was told that I had done a good job on the completion of my second training session. Management is incompetent and gets offended when asked about job scenarios he/she doesn't understand, yet expects the less experienced employee to understand the same material. Mentors would either ignore requests for assistance or postpone it. I even had one mentor to ask if he could postpone assisting me so that he could help his friend with his resume. You may ask, "Why didn't you report it?" Remember....reporting issues will only get you fired... It's already been proven...

Pros: I worked at Cerner for almost 8 years in various roles. The best part of working here was the people I worked with. I loved my coworkers and have even stayed close with them years after leaving the company.
Cons: The pay is notoriously stingy, especially for entry-level positions. If you happen to get hired on in one of those positions be prepared to one of the lowest paid associates if you end up moving to a different department. I was in a senior position after working there for 5 years and I was mentoring new associates who were making more than I was who were just hired on. Could be different now that Oracle owns Cerner.

Pros: Good place to start in KC area
Cons: Large company results in slow growth

Pros: Paid training as an entry-level new hire (Dev Academy), modern tech stack, decent work-life-balance even pre-pandemic, time and patience from management so that you can learn and grow.
Cons: When I worked there, in the particular department I was in, there was no real QA team, so engineers did the majority of the functional verification. That put strain on us and made bugs much more likely. Also toward the end, the pay was not competitive and ultimately I took a much higher paying position working remotely.

Pros: Once Oracle bought them out, I was finally paid a competitive salary

Review Title: Good place for learning diverse set of skills, as well as exposure to wide range of interoperability.
Pros: Getting foundational skills or even putting skills learned in college to use. Great for building resume.
Cons: Great for building resume - could be much better at retaining employees. Oracle acquisition has created increasing uncertainty of company direction, including budget priority for lower level staff (non-executive).

Review Title: Good mid-level management on a sinking ship
Pros: In the 2010-2017 era, Cerner was an above-average employer for ex-clinicians in the corporate world. While the pay was somewhat below market average, the benefits (including onsite healthcare facilities, great gym facilities, and travel perks) were great.
Cons: Unfortunately, in the years leading up to and following Cerner's acquisition by Oracle, the upsides have diminished to the point of nonexistence. Onsite healthcare is now dissolved, and all but the main KC campus have been sold off (and even that is disappearing with the company's pending move to Nashville). Pay has not risen to meet market, leading to stark compensation divides between Oracle and Oracle/Cerner employees in the same role.

Pros: Great benefits and great cause/purpose to be working for. Believed in the company and enjoyed the clients that I got to work with.
Cons: Pay was not comparable to similar jobs in the market and they were not able to be competitive enough to keep employees for long. Retention was terrible and we were constantly losing good people and a lot of knowledge and constantly having to train new team members. Teams kept getting smaller and more overworked also leading to retention issues. Also, did not always do the best job of hiring the best people. Often had people joining our team that were not hard workers, that slacked off and were dishonest and were not the right fit for the job.

Pros: You may occasionally work with someone with talent. The clients were really appreciative of the work that you put out. There are endless opportunities to innovate.
Cons: Management here is probably the worst I've encountered in my professional career. They are clueless, and their main function is to eliminate any potential competition. They don't promote the best and most talented to protect their positions within the organization. If you are perceived as talented, they will perceive you as a threat. They are terrible at talent evaluation and the people that get promoted leave you scratching your head. They are terrible at project management and attempts at efficiency have put the entire organization at risks to lose the multi-billion dollar VA Contract.
